bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a garment or item designed, intended or adapted for the purpose of protecting the body from projectiles discharged from a firearm, as defined in section 2 of the Criminal Code, or
a prescribed garment or item;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: body armour permit means a permit issued under section 6 [body armour permit] authorizing a person to possess body armour;
business entity has the same meaning as in the Security Services Act;
crime has the same meaning as in the Security Services Act;
inspector has the same meaning as in the Security Services Act;
security worker licence means a security worker licence issued under section 5 of the Security Services Act;
sell includes offer for sale, expose for sale, have in possession for sale, distribute, give, transfer, lend, send or otherwise dispose of, whether or not for consideration.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prohibition on possession of body armour

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: private investigator has the same meaning as in the Security Services Act;
security consultant has the same meaning as in the Security Services Act;
security guard means an individual who performs the work of, or provides any aspect of the services provided by, a security guard service, as defined in the Security Services Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not possess body armour except under the authority of a valid body armour permit issued in the person's name.
Subsection (2) does not apply to a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: holds a valid security worker licence authorizing the person to perform the work of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an armoured car guard,
a private investigator,
a security consultant,
a security guard, or
a body armour salesperson,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: while the person is in the course of employment under the security worker licence,

holds a valid security business licence for a security business described in paragraph (a), (c), (d), (e), (f) or (g) of the definition of "security business" in the Security Services Act, while the person is in the course of employment in relation to the security business licence, or
is exempt under the regulations.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If the basis on which a person who possesses body armour is exempt under section 2 (3) from the requirement to hold a body armour permit changes so that the exemption no longer applies, the person, within 14 days after that change, must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: return or sell the body armour to the person's employer, if the exemption was based on the person's employment and the employer is exempt from the requirement to hold a body armour permit,
destroy the body armour, or
sell the body armour to a person who holds a valid security business licence authorizing the sale of body armour.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An individual may apply to the registrar for a body armour permit or renewal of a body armour permit.
An application for a body armour permit or renewal must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be made in the form and manner required by the registrar,
include authorizations for the registrar to carry out the prescribed checks regarding the applicant or permit holder, and
be accompanied by the prescribed fee.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An applicant for a body armour permit or the renewal of a body armour permit must meet all conditions and requirements imposed by this Act or the regulations.
The registrar may refuse to issue or renew a body armour permit if any of the following applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the applicant or permit holder fails in any way to comply with, or does not meet the requirements of, section 4 [applying for body armour permit];
the registrar considers that the applicant or permit holder has failed to demonstrate a need to possess or continue to possess body armour;
the registrar considers that it is not in the public interest for the applicant or permit holder to possess or continue to possess body armour;
the applicant or permit holder has been convicted of a crime.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar must hold a hearing before making a decision under subsection (1).
The registrar must give the applicant or permit holder written reasons for a decision under subsection (1).
The registrar may issue or renew a body armour permit for a term not exceeding the prescribed period.
The registrar may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: impose any terms and conditions on a body armour permit that the registrar considers appropriate, and
amend or remove those terms and conditions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar must give the applicant or permit holder written reasons for a decision under subsection (2).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Terms and conditions of body armour permit
bcl:section.bcl:text: The following are terms and conditions of every body armour permit:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the permit holder must carry the permit at all times when body armour is in the permit holder's possession;
the permit holder, when having body armour in the permit holder's possession, must produce the body armour permit on the request of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an inspector, or
a peace officer;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the permit holder must report to the registrar within 14 days of its occurrence,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the theft or loss of the permit,
a change in the permit holder's employment, if possession of body armour under the permit is for the purposes of that employment,
a change in the permit holder's residential address, or
a charge being laid or a conviction entered against the holder for a crime;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on or before the last day of the term of the body armour permit, the permit holder must

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: surrender the permit to the registrar, and
provide evidence satisfactory to the registrar that the body armour has been

bcl:clause.bcl:text: returned or sold to the person's employer if possession of body armour under the permit was for the purposes of employment and the employer is exempt from the requirement to hold a body armour permit,
sold to a person who holds a valid security business licence authorizing the sale of body armour;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the permit holder must

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: comply with this Act and the regulations, and
comply with the terms and conditions of the permit;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the permit holder must not allow another person to use the body armour permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as authorized under this Act, a person who does not hold a valid security business licence or a valid security worker licence, authorizing the sale of body armour, must not sell body armour to another person.
A person who holds a valid security business licence or a valid security worker licence, authorizing the sale of body armour, must not sell body armour to another person unless that other person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: holds a valid body armour permit, or
is exempt from the requirement to hold a body armour permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who holds a valid security business licence authorizing the sale of body armour must not employ another person to sell body armour unless that other person holds a valid security worker licence authorizing the person to sell body armour.

The Security Services Act applies in relation to a security business licence authorizing the sale of body armour and, for that purpose, the references in sections 15 (1) (d) (ii), 16 (5) (a), 31 (a), 34 (1), 35 (1) (a) and (5) and 42 (1) (a) and (b) and (3) of that Act to "this Act" are deemed to include this section.
This section does not apply to a person who sells body armour only on a wholesale basis and only to a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: holds a valid security business licence authorizing the sale of body armour, or
sells body armour on a wholesale basis.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Body armour permit cancellation or suspension

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may cancel, or suspend for a period of time, a body armour permit for any reason under section 5 (1) [refusal of body armour permit].
The registrar must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: hold a hearing before making a decision under subsection (1), and
provide the permit holder with written reasons for the decision.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If under subsection (1) the registrar cancels a body armour permit, the permit holder, immediately or within the period specified by the registrar in the decision or reasons, must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: surrender the permit to the registrar, and
provide evidence satisfactory to the registrar that the body armour has been

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: returned or sold to the person's employer, if possession of the body armour under the permit was for the purposes of employment and the employer is exempt from the requirement to hold a body armour permit,
destroyed, or
sold to a person who holds a valid security business licence authorizing the sale of body armour.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If under subsection (1) the registrar suspends a body armour permit for a period of time, the permit holder, immediately or within the period specified by the registrar in the decision or reasons, must surrender the permit and the body armour to the registrar for that period.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Summary action to protect the public

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the registrar considers it necessary to protect the public, the registrar, immediately and without notice, may cancel, or suspend for a period of time, a body armour permit.
As soon as practicable after making a decision under subsection (1), the registrar must provide the permit holder with written notice of and reasons for the decision.

A body armour permit holder who receives a notice under subsection (2) must immediately surrender the permit and body armour to the registrar or, if the notice is delivered by an inspector or a peace officer, to the inspector or peace officer, and may file a written reply with the registrar within 15 days after the date of the notice.
Section 29 (4) to (7) of the Security Services Act applies to a suspension or cancellation under this section and, for that purpose, a reference in that section

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to a licence is deemed to include a body armour permit referred to in subsection (1) of this section, and
to subsection (3) is deemed to be a reference to subsection (3) of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the permit holder does not file a written reply to a registrar's notice that the body armour permit is cancelled or the registrar's decision under section 29 (4) of the Security Services Act, as that section applies under subsection (4) of this section, results in the body armour permit being cancelled, the registrar may destroy the body armour at the expiration of the 15-day period under subsection (3) of this section or upon giving written reasons under section 29 (6) of the Security Services Act, as applicable.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An inspector may conduct an inspection for one or both of the following purposes:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: determining whether a person is in compliance with this Act, the regulations or the terms and condition of the person's body armour permit;
assisting the registrar in making a decision under section 5 [refusal of body armour permit], 9 [permit cancellation or suspension] or 10 [summary action to protect the public].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Enforcement provisions of Security Services Act apply in relation to body armour permit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 32 [inspection powers] of the Security Services Act applies to an inspection under section 11 of this Act and, for that purpose, a body armour permit holder is deemed to be engaged in security work as defined in the Security Services Act.
Section 33 [warrants] the Security Services Act applies in relation to an inspection under section 11 of this Act.

The registrar must deal with complaints from the public respecting matters that relate to body armour permits and for that purpose section 34 [complaints process] of the Security Services Act applies.
After giving a person an opportunity to be heard, the registrar may impose an administrative penalty on the person if the person contravenes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a prescribed provision of this Act or the regulations in relation to body armour permits, or
a term or condition of a body armour permit,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: and, for that purpose, sections 35 [administrative penalties], 36 [amount of administrative penalty], 37 [notice of administrative penalty], 38 [due date of administrative penalty], 39 [enforcement of administrative penalty], 40 [revenue from administrative penalties] and 41 [limitation period] of the Security Services Act apply.
Section 42 [injunction] of the Security Services Act applies for the purposes of body armour permits.

Section 46 [compensation and restitution] of the Security Services Act applies for the purposes of an offence under section 13 [offences] of this Act and, for that purpose, an offence under section 13 is deemed to be an offence under the Security Services Act.
A person who contravenes any of the following commits an offence:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 2 (2) [prohibition on possession of body armour];
section 3 [terms of exemption];

a term or condition of a body armour permit, including without limiting this, terms and conditions described in section 7 (a) to (f) [terms of body armour permit] and terms and conditions imposed on the body armour permit by the registrar;
section 9 (3) or (4) [body armour permit cancellation or suspension];
section 10 (3) [summary action to protect the public];
subsection (3), (5) or (6) of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who contravenes section 8 (1) or (2) commits an offence.
When applying for a body armour permit or when requested, ordered or directed by the registrar or an inspector to provide information, a person must not provide false or misleading information.

A person does not commit an offence under subsection (3) if, at the time the information was supplied, the person did not know that the information was false or misleading and, with the exercise of reasonable diligence, could not have known that the information was false or misleading.

A person must not obstruct, impede or refuse to admit an inspector or a peace officer who is exercising powers or performing duties under this Act or a warrant issued under, or for the purposes of enforcing, this Act.
A person must not use a body armour permit that has been issued to another person.

If a business entity commits an offence under subsection (2), an employee, officer, director, partner or agent of the business entity who authorizes, permits or acquiesces in the commission of the offence also commits an offence.
Subsection (7) applies whether or not the business entity is prosecuted for the offence.
A charge for an offence under this section may not be laid more than one year after the commission of the offence.
Section 5 of the Offence Act does not apply for the purposes of this Act.
An individual who commits an offence under section 13 is liable on conviction to a fine of not more than $10 000 or imprisonment for not longer than 6 months, or both.
A business entity that commits an offence under section 13 (2) is liable on conviction to a fine of not more than $100 000.
If the registrar imposes an administrative penalty on a person, a prosecution for an offence under this Act for the same contravention may not be brought against the person.
A person who has been charged with an offence under this Act may not be subject to an administrative penalty in respect of the circumstances that gave rise to the charge.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The registrar must establish and maintain a registry in which the registrar must keep a record of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: every body armour permit issued by the registrar and the current status of the permit,
every security business licence and security worker licence, authorizing the sale of body armour, issued by the registrar and the current status of the licence, and
every application for a body armour permit, security business licence or security worker licence that is refused by the registrar and the reasons for the refusal.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 47 of the Security Services Act applies in relation to this Act and, for that purpose, a reference in that section to a "licence" or a "document" is deemed to include body armour permits and documents in the registrar's records respecting a body armour permit.

Section 48 of the Security Services Act applies to a notice, request or written reasons under this Act and, for that purpose, a notice, request or written reasons under this Act are deemed to be a notice, request or written reasons referred to in Part 4 of the Security Services Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An applicant or permit holder may request the registrar to reconsider a decision under section 5 (1) [refusal of body armour permit], 6 (2) [body armour permit], 9 (1) [body armour permit cancellation or suspension] or 12 (4) [administrative penalties].
The time limits in section 51 (1) (a) and (b), and section 51 (2) and (3), of the Security Services Act apply for the purposes of a request under subsection (1) of this section.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 50 of the Security Services Act applies in relation to body armour permits and, for that purpose, a reference in that section to a "licence" is deemed to include a body armour permit.
The registrar may hold a hearing under this Act in writing, electronically or orally or by any combination of written, electronic or oral hearings.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Seizure of body armour without a warrant

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an inspector or a peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing that a person is in possession of body armour in a public place and, on request of the inspector or peace officer, the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: refuses or is unable to produce a valid body armour permit, and
is unable to satisfy the inspector or peace officer that the person is exempt under section 2 (3) from the requirement to hold a body armour permit,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the inspector or peace officer, without a warrant, may search the person and any personal property in that person's possession and seize any body armour found.

Section 23 (4) and sections 24 to 24.2 of the Offence Act apply in respect of body armour seized under subsection (1) of this section and, for the purposes of section 23 (4) of the Offence Act, an inspector is deemed to be a peace officer.

If, under section 24 (2) (a) of the Offence Act, a justice orders that body armour referred to in subsection (2) of this section be detained, despite section 24 (3) of the Offence Act, the body armour may be detained for up to one year before an order under section 24 (5) of that Act, authorizing its continued detention, is required.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations referred to in section 41 of the Interpretation Act.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting forms of applications and body armour permits;
prescribing garments and items for the purposes of paragraph (b) of the definition of "body armour" in section 1 [definitions];
prescribing checks regarding applicants for the purposes of section 4 (2) (b) [applying for body armour permit];
prescribing fees for the purpose of section 4 (2) (c) [applying for body armour permit] which may be different depending on the duration of the body armour permit;
prescribing a maximum period for the purposes of section 6 (1) [body armour permit];
prescribing the information that an applicant for a body armour permit is required to provide;
authorizing the registrar to exempt a person for a prescribed period from the requirement to hold a body armour permit despite any provision of the Act if the registrar is satisfied that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the person does not reside in British Columbia and the nature of the person's proposed activities in British Columbia make it desirable that the person be authorized to possess body armour, or
because of an imminent risk to the person's safety, it is desirable that the person be authorized to possess body armour;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing provisions for the purposes of section 12 (4) [administrative penalty provisions];
establishing an offence for the contravention of a regulation and prescribing a penalty for that offence up to the maximum penalties set out in section 14 (1) [offence penalties].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transition — sale and possession of body armour

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 2 (2) [prohibition on possession of body armour] does not apply for a period of 6 months after the date this section comes into force to a person who, on that date, is in possession of body armour.

Section 8 (1), (2) and (3) [licences to sell body armour] does not apply for a period of 6 months after the date this section comes into force to a person who, on that date, is in possession of body armour for the purpose of selling that body armour to another person.

Section 2 (a) of the Security Services Act does not apply for a period of 6 months after the date this section comes into force to a person who, on that date, is employed by a body armour vendor to perform security work described in paragraph (g) of the definition of security work in section 1 of that Act.

Section 11 (2) of the Security Services Act does not apply for a period of 6 months after the date this section comes into force to a person who, on that date, carries on a security business described in paragraph (g) of the definition of security business in section 1 of that Act.

bcl:editorialnote.in:em: [Note: See Table of Legislative Changes for the status of sections 24 to 28.]

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Act comes into force by regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in Council.
